                    - Special personal data shall not be processed unless the processing is  carried  out  for  the  protection  of  the  legitimate  activities  of  a body or association which

                                - (a) is established for non-profit purposes,

                                - (b) exists for political, philosophical, religious or trade union purposes;

                                - (d) does not involve disclosure of the personal data to a third party without the consent of the data subject.

(6) The processing of special personal data shall be presumed to be necessary where it is required

                                - (a) for the purpose  of or in connection with a legal proceeding,

                                - (b) to obtain legal advice,

                                - (c) for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal rights,

                                - (d) in the course of the administration of justice, or

                                - (e) for medical purposes and the processing is

                                  - (i) undertaken by a health professional, and

                                  - (ii) pursuant to a duty of confidentiality between patient and health professional.

                    - In  this  section,  'medical  purposes'  includes  the  purposes  of preventive medicine, medical diagnosis, medical research, provision of care and treatment and the  management  of healthcare services by a medical or dental practitioner or a legally recognised traditional healer.

                    - A person shall not process special personal data in respect of race or ethnic origin unless the processing of the special personal data is

(a) necessary for the identification and elimination of discriminatory practices, and

                      - (b) carried  out  with  appropriate  safeguards  for  the  rights  and freedoms of the data subject.

(9) The collection of biometric data for subscriber registration shall require  explicit  consent  and  must  be  in accordance  with  the  principles outlined in this Act.

(10) The Minister may in consultation with the Authority by legislative instrument prescribe further  conditions  which  may  be  taken  by  a  data controller for the maintenance of appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of a data subject related to processing of special personal data.

provisions.title: Consent for the processing of personal data of a child
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires data controllers to get permission from a parent or guardian before using a child's personal information, unless the law allows it. The consent must be clear and freely given, and parents can withdraw it at any time, after which the data controller must stop processing the child's data. Data controllers must also try to verify a user's age to ensure parental consent is obtained when necessary.
provisions.rawText:
68. (1) A data controller shall obtain the consent of a parent or legal guardian before processing the personal data of a child for  any purpose, unless  such processing is permitted or required by law.

(2) The consent obtained shall be clear, explicit, specific, informed, and freely given, and shall be obtained in a manner that is appropriate to the age and maturity of the child.

(3) A data controller shall make reasonable efforts to verify that consent has been given by a parent or legal guardian before processing personal data of a child, considering appropriate technology and best practices.

(4) Parents or legal guardians shall have the right to withdraw consent for the processing of their child's personal data at any time.

(5) A data controller shall provide parents or legal guardians with easy and  accessible  means  to  withdraw  consent  and  shall  immediately  cease processing the child's data upon receipt of a withdrawal request.

(6)  Where  a  child  provides  personal  data  directly  to  an  application  or platform, the data controller shall implement age verification mechanisms to determine whether parental consent is necessary.

provisions.title: Demand for medical information or health records
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects the privacy of your medical information by limiting when it can be shared with others. Generally, your consent is required before your medical data can be disclosed, but there are exceptions for public health emergencies and legally required situations. This ensures that your health information remains confidential unless there's a valid reason for its release.
provisions.rawText:
69. (1)  Except provided by law, a data controller is not required to disclose medical data or health records to third parties.

(2) A contract that demands the disclosure of medical data without free, explicit and informed consent of the data subject shall be unenforceable.

(3) Subject to subsection (4) and (5), a data subject shall not be required to provide medical data or health records to any person which

                      - (a) consist of information related to the physical, mental health or mental condition of that data subject, or

                      - (b) has  been  made  by  or  on  behalf  of  a  health  professional  in connection with the care of that data subject.

(4)  In  accordance  with  the  Public  Health  Act,  2012 (Act 851), medical data shall be processed without consent of the data subject if it necessary for contact tracing and outbreak control.

(5) A person other than healthcare providers and medical administrators, shall not process information relating to medical data or health records unless it is reasonably necessary for the: (a) Certification as to medical fitness for work under law; (b) Performance of  an employer's reporting obligations  on persons with disabilities under law; (c) Payment of compensation as required by law; and (d) Enforcement of a court order.

provisions.title: Exemption related to religious or philosophical beliefs of data subject
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows religious organizations and institutions to process personal data related to religious or philosophical beliefs of their members or individuals connected to the institution. This is permitted only if the processing aligns with the organization's objectives and is necessary for achieving its aims. However, these exemptions cannot be used to prevent essential data processing.
provisions.rawText:
70. (1) The prohibition on processing of personal data related to religious or philosophical beliefs does not apply in specific circumstances where:

(a) processing is carried out by a spiritual or religious organization or its branch concerning its members. (b) processing is carried out by an institution founded on religious or philosophical  principles,  provided  it  aligns  with  the  institution's objectives and is necessary to achieve its aims. These  exemptions  are  not  to  be  misused  to  obstruct  essential  data

(2) processing.

provisions.title: Rectification, blocking, erasure and destruction of personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: If the Data Protection Authority finds that your personal data is inaccurate, they can order the organization holding your data to correct or delete it. The organization must also inform any third parties they shared the incorrect data with about the changes. This ensures that inaccurate information is not perpetuated.
provisions.rawText:
71. (1) Where the Authority is satisfied on a complaint of a data subject that personal data on that data subject is inaccurate, the Authority may order the data controller to

(a) rectify,

                    - (b) block,

                    - (c) erase, or

                    - (d) destroy the data.

(2) Subsection (1) applies whether or not the data is an accurate record of information received or obtained by the data controller from the data subject or a third party.

(3) Where the data is an accurate record of the information, the Authority may make an order requiring the data controller to supplement the statement of the true facts which the Authority considers appropriate.

(4) Where the data complained of has been rectified, blocked

supplemented, erased or destroyed, the data controller is required to notify third parties to whom the data has been previously disclosed of the rectification, blocking, supplementation, erasure or destruction.

(5) To determine whether it is reasonably practicable to require the notification, the Authority shall have regard to the number of persons to be notified.

## Data Protection Register

provisions.title: Establishment of Data Protection Register
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision creates a Data Protection Register to be managed by the Authority. Data controllers are required to register, creating a central list of organizations handling data. This will help the Authority keep track of data handlers.
provisions.rawText:
72. (1) There is established by this Act a register of data controllers to be known as the Data Protection Register.

  - The Authority shall keep and maintain the Register.

            - A data controller shall register with the Authority.

provisions.title: Application for registration
provisions.plainLanguage: To register as a data controller, you must apply to the Authority and provide details about your business, data processing activities, and security measures. Providing false information during the application process is a punishable offense. Each data controller location and related company must register separately.

provisions.title: Right to refuse registration
provisions.plainLanguage: The Data Protection Authority can deny registration if the application is incomplete, lacks proper data protection measures, or the applicant is deemed unsuitable. Applicants will be informed of the refusal and can appeal to the High Court. A rejected application does not prevent a person from applying again in the future.
provisions.rawText:
74. (1) The Authority shall not grant an application for registration under this Act where

    - (a) the particulars provided for inclusion in an entry in the Register are insufficient.

    - (b) the appropriate safeguards for the protection of the privacy of the data subject have not been provided by the data controller; and

    - (c) in the opinion of the Authority, the person making the application for registration does not merit the grant of the registration.

    - Where the Authority refuses an application for registration as a data  controller,  the  Authority  shall  inform  the  applicant  in  writing  within twenty-one working days after submission of an application

                      - (a) of its decision and the reasons for the refusal, and

                      - (b) the applicant may apply for judicial review to the High Court against the refusal.

(3) A  refusal  of  an  application  for  registration  is  not  a  bar  to reapplication.

provisions.title: Grant of certificate of registration
provisions.plainLanguage: If an applicant meets the requirements, the Authority will register them and provide a certificate after application approval, upon payment of a fee. The Authority must issue the certificate within seven working days, and the data controller must display copies at all outlets. The registration certificate is valid for twelve months.
provisions.rawText:
75.

            - The Authority shall (a) register an applicant if the applicant has satisfied the conditions required for registration provide  the  applicant  with  a  certification  of  registration  upon

                      - (b) approval of the application.

(2) The applicant shall pay a prescribed fee upon registration.

(3)  The  Authority shall issue a registration certificate within a period no longer than seven working days after approval of application.

(4) Upon receipt of certificate, copies of the certificate shall be displayed at all outlets of the data controller.

(5)  A  certificate of registration issued under this Act shall be  valid for a period of twelve months.

provisions.title: Renewal of registration
provisions.plainLanguage: Data controllers must renew their registration annually to continue processing personal data. Failure to renew on time will result in a halt to data processing and potential fines, with a compliance report required during the renewal process. A delay of more than three months in renewing registration incurs a penalty and monthly interest.
provisions.rawText:
76. (1) Registration shall be renewed every twelve months.

(2) A data controller whose registration certificate has expired shall cease processing of personal data until after renewal of registration certificate.

  - A data controller in the process of renewing their registration shall have to produce a compliance report.

(4) A data controller who fails to renew their registration or delays the renewal process for a period longer than three months shall be subject to an administrative penalty of five thousand penalty units which will attract a five percent monthly interest.

provisions.title: Removal from register
provisions.plainLanguage: A data controller can request to be removed from the Authority's register at any time. Upon receiving the request and required documentation, the Authority is obligated to remove the data controller's name. This gives data controllers control over their registration status.
provisions.rawText: 77. The Authority shall, at the request of the data controller to whom an entry in  the  Register  relates  and  after  submission  of  necessary  documentation, remove the data controller's name from the Register at any time.

provisions.title: Cancellation or suspension of registration
provisions.plainLanguage: The Data Protection Authority can cancel or suspend a data controller's registration if they fail to meet data processing and security standards, provide inaccurate information, or mishandle personal data. This provision ensures that data controllers follow the rules and keep people's information safe.
provisions.rawText:
78 . (1) The Authority has the power to cancel a registration for good cause.

(2) A registered data controller shall may have their registration cancelled or suspended under the following circumstances:

                  - (a) failure to adhere to prescribed standards for data processing and security.

                  - (b) supplying inaccurate details during registration or renewal processes.

                  - (c) handling personal information without the necessary legal basis or consent.

                  - (d) inadequate safeguards leading to unauthorized access, loss, or exposure of personal data.

                  - (e) neglecting to update or maintain registration information within the mandated period.

provisions.title: Processing of personal data without registration prohibited
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision prohibits data controllers from processing personal data if they are not registered under the Act. Registration is a prerequisite for any data processing activities. This ensures that all data processing is done by entities that are known and accountable.
provisions.rawText: 79. A data controller who has not been registered under this Act shall not process personal data.

provisions.title: Access by the public
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision ensures the public can view the information in the Authority's register. The Authority must provide ways for the public to inspect the register and must also provide copies of specific entries for a fee.
provisions.rawText:
80. (1)  The  Authority  shall  provide  facilities  to  make  the  information contained  in  the  Register  available  for  inspection  by  members  of  the public.

(2) The Authority shall supply a member of the public with a copy of the particulars contained in an entry made in the Register on payment of the prescribed fee.

provisions.title: Duty to notify changes
provisions.plainLanguage: Data controllers must inform the Authority of any changes to their registered information within 10 working days. Failure to do so will result in a fine. This ensures the Authority has up-to-date information.
provisions.rawText:
81. (1) A data controller shall notify the Authority of changes in the registered particulars within ten working days.

(2) A data controller who contravenes subsection (1) shall be subject to an administrative penalty of five thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Failure to register
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision penalizes entities that process personal data without registering as data controllers. Companies that don't register within three months of being established also face fines. The penalty for either violation ranges from 2,000 to 100,000 penalty units.
provisions.rawText:
82. (1) A  person  who  fails  to  register  as  a  data  controller  but  processes personal data shall be subject to an administrative penalty of not less than two thousand penalty units and more than a hundred thousand penalty units.

(2) A person who fails to register as a data controller within three months after incorporation shall be subject to an administrative penalty of not less than  two  thousand  penalty  units  and  not  more  than  hundred  thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Assessable processing
provisions.plainLanguage: The Minister can designate certain data processing activities as "assessable processing" if they pose a risk to individuals' data or privacy. The Data Protection Authority must review these activities for compliance, and data controllers must wait for approval before proceeding. Violating this section can lead to significant penalties.
provisions.rawText:
83. (1)  The  Minister  may  by  Executive  Instrument  specify  actions  which constitute  assessable  processing  if  the  Minister  considers  the  assessable processing likely to

          - (a) cause substantial damage or substantial distress to a data subject, or

          - (b) otherwise significantly prejudice the privacy rights of a data subject;

(2) On receipt of an application for registration, the Authority shall consider

                    - (a) whether  the  processing  to  which  the  notification  relates  is assessable, or

                    - (b) if the assessable processing complies with the provisions of this Act.

(3) The  Authority  shall  within  twenty-eight  days  from  the  day  of receipt of the application, inform the data controller whether the processing is likely to comply with the provisions of this Act.

(4) The Authority may extend the initial period by a further period which does not exceed fourteen days or other period that the Authority may specify.

(5) The assessable processing in respect of which a notification has been given to the Authority shall not be carried on unless

                    - (a) the period of twenty-eight days has elapsed, or

                    - (b) before the end of that period, the data controller receives a notice from the Authority under subsection (3).

(6) A data  controller  who  contravenes  this  section  commits  an  offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than one hundred and fifty thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not more than five years or to both.

provisions.title: Appointment of data protection officers
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires organizations that control data to appoint a qualified Data Protection Officer (DPO). The DPO will ensure the organization complies with data protection laws and regulations. Organizations that fail to appoint a DPO will face a fine.
provisions.rawText:
84. (1) A data controller shall appoint a certified and qualified person to serve as a data protection officer.

(2)  A  person  appointed  as  a  data  protection  officer  shall  be trained and certified by the Authority.

(3) The data protection officer is responsible for

                        - (a) Monitoring the data controller's compliance with the provisions of this Act.

                        - (b) Updating the data controller or processor on regulatory changes and updates.

                        - (c) Advising  the  data  controller  or  processor  on  their  obligations under the Act.

(4) An authorisation under this section may

                      - (a) impose  a  duty  on  a  data  protection  officer  in  relation  to  the Authority, and

                      - (b) confer a function on the Authority in relation to a data protection officer.

  - A data protection officer may be an employee of the data controller.

(6) The Authority shall provide the needed guidelines for the qualification to be appointed as a data protection officer.

(7)   A person shall not be appointed as a data protection officer unless the person satisfies the criteria set by the Authority.

(8) A data controller who fails to appoint a data protection officer shall be subject to an administrative penalty of not less than two thousand penalty units and not more than fifty thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Fees
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority will set fees for its services after discussing them with the Minister. This allows the Authority to fund its operations while ensuring fees are reasonable.
provisions.rawText:
85. The Authority, in consultation with the Minister shall prescribe fees for the purpose of its functions.

Accreditation of data protection service providers

provisions.title: Accreditation of data protection service providers
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that all data protection service providers must obtain a license from the Authority to operate legally. Providing data protection services without a valid license will result in a fine of up to fifty thousand penalty units. This ensures that data protection services are provided by accredited and regulated entities.
provisions.rawText:
86. (1) An individual or institution shall not provide a data protection service within the country unless that person obtains a licence issued by the Authority in accordance with this Act.

(2)  A  person  who  contravenes  (1)  by  providing  data  protection  services without a licence issued by the Authority shall be subject to an administrative penalty of not more than fifty thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Application for accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: To become an accredited data protection service provider, applicants must apply in writing to the Authority, including required documents and fees. Individuals must also undergo training and certification as a data protection professional. The Authority will provide additional guidelines for the application process.
provisions.rawText:
87. (1) A person who seeks to provide a data protection service shall apply in writing to the Authority.

(2) The application shall be made in the prescribed form and accompanied by the:

(a) supporting documentation, and

(b) prescribed fee, that the Authority shall determine.

(3) An individual seeking accreditation as a data protection service provider shall  be  required  to  undergo  training  and  obtain  certification  from  the Authority as a certified data protection professional, or possess an equivalent certification recognised by the Authority.

(4) The Authority shall issue further guidelines in support of the application process.

provisions.title: Grant of accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can grant accreditation to applicants who meet the requirements. The decision will be communicated within 30 days, and the accreditation is subject to specific terms. Misusing the accreditation can result in it being revoked.
provisions.rawText:
88. (1) Where the Authority is satisfied that

(a) the applicant meets the requirements of the Authority for the grant of a licence, the Authority may grant the licence to the applicant,

(2) Upon receiving an application for a licence, the Authority shall provide written notification of its decision to the applicant within thirty working days.

(3) An  accreditation  granted by the  Authority is  subject to the terms  and conditions specified by the Authority.

(4)

(5) An accredited institution who uses a licence for a purpose other than that for which the licence was granted shall have the licence revoked.

provisions.title: Non transferability of accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: An accreditation cannot be transferred from the person who was originally granted the accreditation to someone else. Transferring an accreditation is an offense and will result in a fine.
provisions.rawText:
89. (1)  A  person  granted  an  accreditation  shall  not  transfer  that  licence  to another person.

(2) A person who transfers a licence contrary to subsection (1) commits an offence  and  is  liable  on  summary  conviction  to  a  fine  of  not  less  than  five thousand penalty units and not more than ten thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Validity of accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: A data protection license is valid for one year. Institutions must apply to renew their license at least one month before it expires to avoid potential penalties.
provisions.rawText:
90. (1) A licence granted under this Act is valid for twelve months from the date that the licence is granted.

(2) An accredited institution who intends to continue operations as a data protection  service  provider  shall,  not  later  than  one  month  before  the expiration of the licence, apply to the Authority in writing for a renewal of the licence.

(3) An accredited institution who intends to continue operations as a data protection service provider and fails to begin the renewal process  within the timeline stipulated in (2) may be subject to an administrative penalty.

provisions.title: Suspension of accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can temporarily suspend a license for up to six months if an institution doesn't meet the license requirements. Before suspending a license, the Authority must provide the institution with a 30-day written notice explaining the reasons for the potential suspension. The Authority must also notify the relevant data protection service provider within 28 days of the suspension.
provisions.rawText:
91. (1) The Authority may suspend a licence issued under this Act for a period of not more than six months where the accredited institution fails to comply with a condition specified in the licence.

(2) The Authority shall, before exercising the power of suspension under this section,

          - (a) give the accredited institution thirty days' notice in writing of the intention to do so, and

          - (b) specify in the notice the grounds on which the Authority intends to suspend the licence.

(3) The Authority shall, within twenty-eight days of the suspension of a licence, notify the data protection service provider concerned of the suspension.

provisions.title: Revocation of accreditation
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can revoke a license if it was obtained through fraud, the business has stopped operating, or the licensee has been convicted of certain offenses. A license can also be revoked if the licensee no longer meets the requirements or if allowing them to continue operating would not be in the public's best interest. This ensures that only qualified and ethical businesses maintain their licenses.
provisions.rawText:
92. (1)  The  Authority  may  revoke  a  licence  issued  under  this  Act  if  the Authority considers that

(a) the licence has been obtained by fraud or misrepresentation.

(b) the licensee has ceased to carry on the business for which the licensee is licensed.

(c) the  licensee  has  been  convicted  of  an  offence  under  this  Act  or  an offence involving fraud, dishonesty or moral turpitude.

(d) a circumstance existed at the time the license was granted or renewed that the Authority was unaware of, which would have prevented the Authority from granting or renewing the licence of the licensee if the Authority had been aware of the circumstance at that time.

(e) the licensee no longer meets the requirements for holding the licence; or

(f) it is not in the public interest for the licensee to continue to carry on the business of a licensee.

## Direct Sanctioning Powers of the Authority

provisions.title: Sanctions and penalties
provisions.plainLanguage: Administrative penalties must be paid within 21 working days. Individuals or entities can appeal the penalty decision through the review mechanism detailed in Section 89.
provisions.rawText:
93. (1) Administrative penalties imposed under this section shall be paid within twenty-one working days of issuance of the penalty notice.

(2) Any individual or entity subject to an administrative penalty under this section  may  appeal  against  the  decision  to  impose  the  penalty  through  the established review mechanism outlined in Section 89.

provisions.title: General penalty
provisions.plainLanguage: This section states that if someone violates a part of this law that doesn't already have a specific punishment, they will face an administrative fine. The fine will be between 50,000 and 100,000 penalty units.
provisions.rawText: 94 . A person who contravenes a section of this Act for which a penalty is not provided  shall  be  subject  to  an  administrative  penalty  of  not  less  than  fifty thousand penalty units and not more than hundred thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Review mechanism
provisions.plainLanguage: If a data controller disagrees with a decision made by the Authority, they can request a review within seven working days. The Authority must then review the decision within thirty working days. If the data controller is still not satisfied, they can appeal to the High Court.
provisions.rawText:
95 .(1) In the event that a data controller is dissatisfied with a determination made by the Authority pursuant to this Act, the data controller shall have the right to request a review of the said determination.

(2)  The  data  controller  shall  submit  a  written  request  for  review  to  the Authority within seven working  days  from  the date of receiving the determination.

(3) The request for review shall clearly outline the grounds for the request and any supporting evidence.

(4) Upon receipt of the request for review, the Authority shall promptly acknowledge  the  request  and  provide  the  data  controller  with  information regarding the process.

(5)  The  Authority  shall  review  the  determination  and  make  a  decision within  thirty  working  days,  which  shall  be  communicated  to  the  data controller.

(6)  If the data controller is dissatisfied with the decision on the review, they may seek further redress on appeal through judicial review or other legal remedies available in the High Court.

provisions.title: Basis for cross border transfer of personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This section explains when personal information can be sent outside of Ghana. Generally, companies should try to keep data within Ghana, but they can transfer it if the person agrees, if it's needed for a contract, or if it's crucial to protect someone's well-being, with the Authority's approval. All data, even when transferred, must still be handled according to this law.
provisions.rawText:
96. (1)    Notwithstanding  the  opportunity  to  under  a  cross-border  transfer personal  data  under  subsection  (3),  a  data  controller  shall  make reasonable efforts  to  localise  data  provided  that  data  localisation  does  not  impair  its business or operations.

(2) There shall be no requirement for a data controller to localise personal data unless:

              - (a) the  personal  data  is  critical  to  national  defence,  security  and intelligence of the country; or

              - (b) the  personal  data  concern  national  identity  ID  systems  and  civil registration systems including voter databases

              - (c) the  personal  data  concerns  children's  data,  biometric  data,  health records and genetic data.

(3)  Subject to subsection (2), the Authority may grant approval to a data controller for the cross-border transfer children's data, biometric data, health records  and  genetic  data  with  the  consent  of  the  data  subject  or  any  other person under an obligation in law to make decisions for the data subject for the time-being.

(4) A data controller shall transfer personal data outside Ghana only if the following conditions are met:

(a) the  data  subject  has  provided  written,  free,  explicit  and  informed consent  to  the  proposed  transfer  after  being  informed  of  the  possible  risks involved;and

(b) (i) the  transfer  is  necessary  for  the  performance  of  a  contract,  for administrative, educational, financial, medical or professional reasons, between the data subject and the data controller or for the implementation of pre-contractual measures taken at the data subject's request; or

(ii) the  transfer  is  necessary  for  the  conclusion  or  performance  of  a contract concluded, or for administrative, educational, financial, medical or

professional  reasons  in  the  interest  of  the  data  subject  between  the  data controller and a third party; or

(iii) or the transfer is necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims; or

(iv) the transfer is necessary to protects the vital interests of the data subject or other individuals where the data subject is physically or legally incapable of giving consent; and

(c) the transfer is authorised by the Authority where it involves large-scale data, and in all cases, following an assessment that adequate safeguards for the protection  of  personal  data  are  in  place,  including  appropriate  contractual clauses  and  binding  corporate  rules  or  other  mechanisms  approved  by  the Authority.

(3) In all cases, personal data emanating from Ghana shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

provisions.title: Safeguards prior to transfer of personal data out of Ghana
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision regulates the transfer of personal data outside of Ghana, requiring consent, approval from the Data Protection Authority, and security measures. The Authority can block or condition transfers to protect individuals' rights. Companies handling large amounts of data must assess the impact of transfers to ensure data privacy.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A data controller shall process special personal data out of Ghana upon obtaining consent of all affected data  subjects and upon obtaining approval from the Authority.

  - The Authority may request a person who transfers data to another country to  demonstrate  the effectiveness  of  security  safeguards  and  the  existence  of compelling legitimate interests.

  - The Authority may, in order to protect the rights and fundamental freedoms of data subjects, prohibit, suspend or subject the transfer to such conditions as may be determined by the Authority.

(4) A data controller that processes large-scale data where a data processing activity is likely to pose real risk to the rights and freedoms of a data subject, shall conduct a Transfer Impact Assessment on all data transfers in or outside the jurisdiction subject to the approval of the Authority.

(5) The Authority shall provide relevant guidelines in support of subsection (4).

## Exemptions

provisions.title: National security
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows personal data to be processed without adhering to standard data protection rules if it's for national security or public safety reasons. However, individuals can still sue if they believe their rights were unfairly violated. This ensures a balance between security needs and individual rights.
provisions.rawText:
98. (1) The processing of personal data is exempt from the provisions of this Act for the purposes of

                    - (a) public order,

                    - (b) public safety,

                    - (c) public morality,

                    - (d) national security, or

                    - (e) public interest.

(2) Despite, subsection (1), nothing shall prevent a person from pursuing an action in court whether by injunction or otherwise that their rights have been unfairly prejudiced.

provisions.title: Crime and taxation
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows law enforcement and tax agencies to use personal data for crime prevention, prosecution, and tax collection without being fully restricted by data protection laws. This exemption is in place to ensure that data protection rules do not impede efforts to fight crime or collect taxes. However, this exemption only applies when following standard data protection rules would likely cause issues for the prevention of crime, prosecution of offenders, or collection of taxes.
provisions.rawText:
99. (1) The processing of personal data is exempt from the provisions of this Act for the purposes of

                    - (a) the prevention or detection of crime,

                    - (b) the apprehension or prosecution of an offender, or

                    - (c) the assessment or collection of a tax or duty or of an imposition of a similar nature.

  - Personal data is exempt from the non-disclosure provisions in any case in which

                    - (a) the disclosure is for a purpose mentioned in subsection (1), and

                    - (b) the application of those provisions in relation to the disclosure is likely to prejudice any of the matters mentioned in that subsection.

provisions.title: Health, education and social work
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects the privacy of individuals by restricting the disclosure of sensitive personal data related to their health, education, and social work. This includes health records, student information, and similar data. Disclosure is only allowed if required by law.
provisions.rawText:
100. Personal data on the following subjects shall not be disclosed except where the disclosure is required by law:

                      - (a) personal data which relates to the physical, mental health or mental condition of the data subject,

                      - (b) personal  data  in  respect  of  which  the  data  controller  is  an educational  institution  and  which  relates  to  a  pupil  at  the institution, or

                      - (c) personal data of similar description.

provisions.title: Regulatory activity
provisions.plainLanguage: This section exempts certain data processing activities from the data protection act. Specifically, it allows the processing of personal data to protect the public from malpractice in financial services or to ensure health and safety, as well as for governmental functions like public health administration and disease control. This means that in these specific cases, some data protection rules may not apply.
provisions.rawText:
101. (1) The provisions of this Act do not apply to the processing of personal data for protection of members of the public

                      - (a) against loss or malpractice in the provision of

                              - (i) banking,

                              - (ii) insurance,

                              - (iii) investment,

                              - (iv) other financial services, or

                              - (v) digital services

                              - (vi) management of a body corporate;

                      - (b) against dishonesty or malpractice in the provision of professional services;

                      - (c) against the misconduct or mismanagement in the administration of a non-profit making entity;

                      - (d) to secure the health, safety and welfare of persons at work; or

                      - (e) to protect non-working persons against the risk to health or safety arising out of or in connection with the action of persons at work.

(2)  The  processing  of  personal  data  is  exempt  from  the  subject information  provisions  of  this  Act  if  it  is  for  the  discharge  of  a  function conferred by or under an enactment on

                      - (a) Parliament,

                      - (b) a local government authority,

                      - (c) the administration of public health or public financing of health care, prevention, control of disease and the monitoring and eradication of disease.

provisions.title: Journalism, literature and art
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows journalists, artists, and writers to process personal data for publications if it's in the public interest and full compliance isn't feasible, but they must still protect data security and quality. The government may designate codes of practice to guide decisions about what constitutes "public interest" in these cases. This aims to balance freedom of expression with data protection.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A person shall not process personal data unless

                      - (a) the processing is undertaken by a person for the publication of a literary or artistic material;

                      - (b) the data controller reasonably believes that publication would be in the public interest; and

                      - (c) the data controller reasonably believes that, in all the circumstances, compliance with the provision is incompatible with the special purposes.

  - Subsection (1) does not exempt a data controller from compliance with the data principles related to

                    - (c) further processing,

                    - (d) data subject participation

                    - (e) information quality, and

                    - (f) security safeguards.

(3) For the purposes of subsection (1) (b) , in considering whether the data controller believes that the publication would be in the public interest or is reasonable, regard may be had to the compliance by the data controller with any code of practice which is

                    - (a) relevant to the publication in question, and

                    - (b) designated by the Minister for purposes of this subsection.

provisions.title: Research, history and statistics
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows personal data to be used for research, even if it wasn't the original intention, provided certain rules are followed. Data can be stored indefinitely for research, and research data is exempt from some regulations if the results don't identify individuals. Disclosing data for research or when legally required is also permitted.
provisions.rawText:
103. (1)  The  further  processing  of  personal  data  for  research  purposes  in compliance with the relevant conditions is not to be regarded as incompatible with the purposes for which the data was obtained.

(2) Personal data processed for research purposes in compliance with the relevant conditions may be kept indefinitely.

(3) Personal  data  which  is  processed  only  for  research  purposes  is exempt from the provisions of this Act if

                    - (a) the data is processed in compliance with the relevant conditions, and

                    - (b) the  results  of  the  research  or  resulting  statistics  are  not  made available  in  a  form  which  identifies  the  data  subject  or  any  of them.

(4) Personal data is not to be treated as processed otherwise than for research purposes merely because the data is disclosed

                    - (a) to any person for research purposes only,

                    - (b) to the data subject or a person acting on behalf of the data subject,

                  - (c) at the request or with the consent of the data subject or a person acting on behalf of the data subject, or

                    - (d) in circumstances in which the person making the disclosure has reasonable grounds to believe that the disclosure falls within this section.

Disclosure required by law or made in connection with a legal proceeding 104. Personal data is exempt from the provisions on non-disclosure where the disclosure is required by or under an enactment, any rule of law or by the order of a court.

provisions.title: Domestic purposes
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision exempts individuals using personal data for their own personal, family, or household matters from standard data protection rules. This means you don't have to follow data protection principles when handling personal information within your family or home. The exemption aims to avoid burdening individuals with regulations designed for larger organizations.
provisions.rawText: 105. Personal data which is processed by an individual only for the purpose of that individual's personal, family or household affairs is exempt from the data protection principles.

provisions.title: Confidential references given by data controller
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision exempts confidential references from standard data protection rules when they are provided by a data controller for purposes like education, employment, or appointments. This means organizations giving references don't have to adhere to all data protection principles for those specific references. This aims to allow for candid assessments without undue legal constraints.
provisions.rawText:
106. Personal data is exempt from the data protection principles if it consists of a reference given in confidence by the data controller for the purposes of

                      - (a) education, training or employment of the data subject,

  - (b) the appointment to an office of the data subject, or

  - (c) the provision of any service by the data subject.

provisions.title: Armed Forces
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Armed Forces to withhold personal data if releasing it could weaken their combat effectiveness. This is to ensure that sensitive information doesn't fall into the wrong hands and compromise military operations. The exemption prioritizes national security and the Armed Forces' ability to defend the country.
provisions.rawText: 107. Personal data is exempt from the subject information provisions where the application of the provisions is likely to prejudice the combat effectiveness of the Armed Forces of the Republic.

provisions.title: Judicial appointments and honours
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the government to process personal data when considering someone for a judicial role or national honor without being fully transparent to the individual. This means the person may not be able to see or correct the information used in the decision-making process. The exemption aims to facilitate thorough vetting for these important positions.
provisions.rawText:
108. Personal data processed to:

                            - (a) assess a person's suitability for judicial office, or

            - (b) confer a national honour,exempt from the subject information provisions of this Act.

provisions.title: Public service or ministerial appointment
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision grants the Minister the power to create regulations that exempt personal data used for assessing candidates for government jobs or presidential appointments from certain data protection rules. This could affect the transparency and control individuals have over their information during the application process for these positions. These regulations are created through a legislative instrument.
provisions.rawText:
109. The Minister may by legislative instrument make Regulations to prescribe exemptions from the subject information provisions of personal data processed to assess a person's suitability for

                    - (a) employment by the government, or

                    - (b) any office to which appointments are made by the President.

provisions.title: Examination marks
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision exempts examination marks from certain data protection regulations. This exemption applies when the marks are used to determine or as a consequence of determining examination results. This aims to streamline the processing of exam results by data controllers.
provisions.rawText:
110. Personal data is exempt from the provisions of this Act if it relates to examination marks processed by a data controller

                    - (a) to determine the results of an academic, professional or other examination or to enable the results of the examination to be determined, or

                    - (b) in consequence of the determination of the results.

provisions.title: Examination scripts
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision exempts examination scripts from data protection laws. This means that the information you write in exams is not subject to the same data protection rules as other personal data. This exemption likely streamlines the examination process.
provisions.rawText: 111. Personal data which consists of information recorded by candidates during an academic, professional or other examination is exempt from the provisions of this Act.

provisions.title: Professional privilege
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects the confidentiality of communications between clients and their professional advisors. It ensures that personal data covered by professional privilege, such as lawyer-client or doctor-patient communications, is exempt from subject information requests. This means individuals cannot use subject information provisions to access personal data that would otherwise be protected by professional privilege in legal proceedings.
provisions.rawText:
112. Personal data is exempt from the subject information provisions if it consists of information in respect of which a claim to professional privilege or confidentiality between client and a professional adviser could be maintained in legal proceedings.

Miscellaneous and general provisions

provisions.title: General duties of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority is responsible for guiding and encouraging best practices to ensure everyone follows this law. It can charge fees for its services and will educate the public about their rights and the obligations of data controllers.
provisions.rawText:
113. (1) The Authority shall provide guidelines and promote the observance of good practice to ensure compliance with this Act.

(2) The  Authority  may  charge  the  fees  that the Authority in consultation with the Minister determines for the provision of services by the Authority.

    - The Authority is responsible for conducting public education and awareness campaigns to the public on data subject rights and data controllers' obligations under this Act.

provisions.title: Codes, guidelines and certification
provisions.plainLanguage: The Director-General can create guidelines and certifications to help organizations follow data protection laws. They can also require third-party verification and develop specific rules for sectors like healthcare and finance. This helps ensure that personal data is handled properly across different industries.

provisions.title: International co-operation
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority will work with international organizations to enforce personal data protection laws. This includes assisting other countries with investigations, sharing information, and collaborating with stakeholders to improve international cooperation on data protection. The goal is to create a global network for effective enforcement and data exchange, while safeguarding fundamental rights.

provisions.title: Prohibition to purchase, obtain or disclose personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision makes it illegal to buy, obtain, or share someone else's personal data. Violators could face a fine of up to twenty thousand penalty units, a prison sentence of up to two years, or both. This aims to protect individuals' privacy by preventing unauthorized access to and distribution of their personal information.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A person shall not

                      - (a) purchase the personal data or the information contained in the personal data of another person;

                      - (b) knowingly obtain or knowingly or recklessly disclose the personal data or the information contained in the personal data of another person; or

                      - (c) disclose or cause to be disclosed to another person the information contained in personal data.

    - A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than twenty thousand penalty units or to a term of imprisonment of not more than two years or to both.

provisions.title: Prohibition of sale of personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This law makes it illegal to sell someone else's personal information. Violators will face a fine of up to fifty thousand penalty units. Advertising the sale of personal data is also prohibited.
provisions.rawText:
117. (1) A person who sells or offers to sell personal data of another person commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than fifty thousand penalty units.

    - For this section's purposes, an advertisement indicating that personal data is or may be for sale is an offer to sell the data.

provisions.title: Conditional request for personal data prohibited
provisions.plainLanguage: This law prevents businesses from demanding specific personal information from customers in order to provide them with goods or services. Exceptions exist if a law requires the information or if it's in the public's best interest. Businesses that violate this rule may face a fine.
provisions.rawText:
118. (1) A person who provides goods, facilities or services to the public shall  not  require  a  person  to  supply  or  produce  a  particular  record  as  a condition for the provision of the goods, facilities or services to that person.

(2) Subsection  (1)  does  not  apply  where  the  imposition  of  the requirement is required or authorised under an enactment, rule of law or in the public interest.

                  - A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than fifty thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Transmission of notices by electronic or other means
provisions.plainLanguage: This section clarifies that electronic notices are acceptable if they follow the Authority's guidelines, are readable, and can be referenced later. The Minister can create exceptions to this rule through regulations. This aims to modernize communication methods while maintaining clarity and accessibility.
provisions.rawText:
119. (1) A requirement that a notice, request, particulars or application the notice, request, particulars or application to which this Act applies shall be in writing is satisfied where the text of (a) is transmitted by electronic means in a manner specified by the Authority, (b) is received in legible form, and (c) is capable of being used for subsequent reference. (2) The Minister may by Regulations exempt a notice, request,

particulars or application from these requirements.

provisions.title: Service of notices by the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This section explains how the Authority can officially send notices to individuals, companies, and partnerships. Notices can be delivered by mail, in person, or electronically to a specified email address. The Authority can also use other legal methods to deliver notices.
provisions.rawText:
120. (1) A notice authorised or required by this Act to be served on or given to a person by the Authority may (a) if that person is an individual, be served on that individual by delivery to that individual, (i) by post addressed to that individual at that Individual's usual or last known place of residence or business, (ii) by leaving the notice at that individual's usual or last known place of residence or business, or (iii) by sending it to an electronic mail address specified by the individual for service of notices; (b) if that person is a body corporate or unincorporated, be served on that body (i) by post to the principal officer of the body at its principal office, (ii) by addressing it to the principal officer of the body and leaving it at that office, or (iii) by sending it to an electronic mail address specified by the body for service of notices under this Act; and (c) if that person is a partnership, be served on that partnership (i) by post to the principal office of the partnership, (ii) by addressing it to that partnership and leaving it at

                                  - that office, or

(2) This section does not limit any other lawful method of serving or giving a notice.

provisions.title: Regulations
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Minister to create regulations to further define and implement the Data Protection Act, covering areas like consent, data safeguards, and exemptions. Violating these regulations can lead to a fine. These regulations ensure the law is effectively applied and can adapt to different situations.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) The Minister may in consultation with the Authority by legislative instrument make Regulations to

                      - (a) extend the transitional period for a data controller in existence at the commencement of this Act,

                      - (b) specify the conditions that are to be satisfied for consent to be given,

                      - (c) prescribe  further  conditions  which  may  be  taken  by  a  data controller for the maintenance of appropriate safeguards, for the rights and freedoms of a data subject related to the processing of special personal data,

                      - (d) make different provisions for different situations,

                      - (e) exempt notices,  requests,  particulars  or  applications  from  the requirements under the Act, and

                      - (f) provide generally for any other matter necessary for the effective implementation of the provisions of this Act.

(2) A person who commits an offence under the Regulations is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than five thousand penalty units.

provisions.title: Interpretation
provisions.plainLanguage: This section defines the key terms used in this law, such as "personal data," "data controller," and "processing," to ensure everyone understands the specific meaning of these terms within the context of the law. These definitions are important for interpreting the law correctly and understanding your rights and responsibilities.

provisions.title: Repeals and savings
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision eliminates the Data Protection Act of 2012. The repeal means the law is no longer valid, and any regulations or protections it provided are removed.
provisions.rawText: - The Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) is hereby repealed.

provisions.title: Transitional Provisions
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision ensures that any existing data protection approvals issued by the previous authority remain valid. The new Authority will honor these approvals until they expire or the Authority decides to revoke or change them. This ensures a smooth transition and avoids immediate disruption for organizations already compliant with data protection rules.
provisions.rawText: 124. Any  decision, authorisation, permit or certificate issued by the predecessor of the Authority in respect of  data protection shall remain valid until  it  is  revoked,  cancelled,  terminated  by  the  Authority,  or  expires  in accordance with its terms.

provisions.title: Commencement
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision states that the Minister will announce the date when the law goes into effect by publishing it in the Gazette. This makes the commencement date public knowledge.
provisions.rawText: 125. The Minister shall specify the date when this Act shall come into force by publication in the G azette.
